data.text: What Do Cyclists Need in Their First Aid Kits?
My first aid kit consists of four band-aids. What items does a cyclist include in a good first aid kit?

I use https://eu.alpkit.com/products/solo-adventure-first-aid-kit, it's based on minimum requirements for mountain marathons. I add extra drugs and things I know how to use. I take an ankle bandage as I've turned it a few times now
Solo Adventure First Aid Kit supply pack
eu.alpkit.com
data.author: Tom Hall

data.text: Thanks for the visual. It gives me a better idea of the things I need.
data.author: James Saunders

data.text: I'd say don't get a kit too big there is random stuff in you don't know how to use. If you do a first aid course or have particular injuries you've had before or little bits you use in "real life" add them (for me when hiking it was blister, I like Compeed)
data.author: Tom Hall

data.text: Good advice. Sometimes my knee goes a little loose so some kind of bandage to wrap it is a smart addition to the kit.

data.text: I took a hard fall recently with much blood in several location on my body. Here is what you need: -gauze pads to slap the Neosporin on and then on place the gauze pad on the wound. Leave it there. -Neosporin -flexi-tape. The kind that sticks to itself and is flexible. If you are sweaty or bloody band-aids won‚Äôt stick. -LARGE bandaids -larger gauze pads or a sanitary pad to slap on top of the smaller ones with the Neosporin. Then secure with the flexi-tape. -ibuprofen or Tylenol - benedryl for bee/wasp stings -tweezers
data.author: Mary Ann Latzgo Padglick

data.text: I guess the tweezers are for splinters or little stones that get lodged in the skin. Thanks for the advice that comes from experience. I‚Äôve had a couple of tumbles off the bike in my life but nothing too serious.

data.text: Antihistamines (pills and cream), anti-inflammatories, meds for GI distress, duct tape, assorted sizes of plasters, antibiotic ointment, alcohol wipes, nonstick sterile gauze pads, superglue, scissors, tweezers, tampons, flexible stretchy bandage roll. I carry everything in a roll-top dry bag. Don‚Äôt carry anything you don‚Äôt know how to use.

data.text: have a look into lucillin spray. It's developed for animals as a spray to stop infections. I use it for treating dog cuts/ bites having 6 it's my go to antiseptic. But it's approved for human use - there is nothing better for healing cuts and stopping infection.

data.text: Keep extra supplies in your vehicle in case you need more.
data.author: Lorraine Warner

data.text: I get around by BMW (Bus-Metro-Walk) in the winterüòÜ Metro is our word for subway. My bike is my main mode of transportation. I even tried biking in the winter but I chose my days because it can be dangerous on snow and ice. All this to say that I don‚Äôt drive.
data.author: James Saunders

data.text: ok. I live in Rural Pennsylvania. You have to drive. No public transportation, no Uber.
data.author: Lorraine Warner

data.text: 2+ tourniquets, 1+ twin pack chest seals, combat gauze, extra gauze, gloves. Most injuries you incur will be minor, can wait to receive medical attention, and won't prevent you from being able to bike to get medical attention (although they may slow you down). This list is barebones what you need for most injuries that are life threatening, require you act fast, prevent you from traveling, and that you can feasibly provide immediate treatment for yourself until you can receive actual medical care, as long as you take the time to watch the free stop the bleed videos beforehand (taking a class is preferred of course!). If you still have space I would add glucose tablets, an emergency blanket, a triangle bandage, trauma scissors if you don't already carry a cutting device, etc. If space weren't a concern I would recommend everyone have Narcan in their first aid kit too. I have cpr/aed/first aid certification through the Red Cross, as well as BLS and Stop The Bleed certification through AHA. I would recommend any/all of these classes.

data.text: I do not Carry. I figure if I get so hurt I need 1. I'm probably heading to the hospital

data.text: About 4 bandaids, a packet of 2 tylenol, a small tube of neosporin+pain relief, some medical tape and a couple of wet wipes from KFC in a ziplock baggie, and my water bottle. And my phone. My solo rides seldom take me more than an a couple hundred ft from a house or business though.
data.author: Jeff Ragsdale

data.text: Think about what might hurt you. The Sun (sunscreen, aloe vera) Dehydration(hydralyte tablets) Road rash(anti-septic, jelo-net, XL bandaids) Bad hygiene(gastrolyte, hand sanitiser, toilet paper, pain killers) Creepy crawlies (stingoes) In case of emergency break glass(signal whistle, $50 in cash, change for a payphone and an ICE phone number)
data.author: Richard Neville

data.text: Different sized bandages and plasters, bum pills (go and stop for camping), sting wipes, pain killers, mirror for eyes and face, eye rinse, small scissors. Few other bits and bobs.

data.text: two Benadryl, one Pepcid, two bandaids (one large one medium), Neosporin, benadryl cream, eye drops, 2 aspirin, 2 Tylenol, 2 baby wipes, hand sanitizer ---the Benadryl and Pepcid can be taken together as a first line of defense in replace of an epipen. the neosporin, eye drops and benadryl are tiny little packets you can get at walgreens and are great to have. everything fits neatly with my spare tube under my saddle

data.text: 1. Bandages large enough to cover road rash (I like to bring gauze, scissors, and blue tape because i have sensitive skin that doesn't usually like standard bandaid adhesive) 2. Alcohol wipes 3. Neosporin 4. Benadryl 5. Ibuprofen 6. Tylenol 7. Aloe (for sun burns) 8. Sunscreen (to hopefully prevent sunburns) 9. Wipes (like the kind you use on your fanny not antiseptic ones, for general cleanup purposes)
